body:
@lbendig : Thoughts on the above? 
Do you think you will have cycles to try out the approach I'm proposing?
@shirshanka Thanks for your suggestion, I think it should yields to the same result but in a easier way. I'll implement it this week.

Addressed all the minor comments, will create separate Jiras / Issues for couple of bigger items: 
1. When we restore all scheduled jobs from Kafka when ClusterMaster restarts, we might not be able to fully restore the state since some job events might be lost due to Kafka retention 
2. Comprehensive testing of URIs for FlowSpecs

Thanks for the continued review!!

@sungpeo : There seem to be test failures. Can you figure out why they are failing? 

./gradlew :gobblin-core:test


-- snippet from Travis build: https://travis-ci.org/linkedin/gobblin/jobs/204660255

Gradle suite > Gradle test > gobblin.source.extractor.watermark.TimestampWatermarkTest.testGetWatermarkConditionMySql STARTED
Gradle suite > Gradle test > gobblin.source.extractor.watermark.TimestampWatermarkTest.testGetWatermarkConditionMySql FAILED
    java.lang.NullPointerException at TimestampWatermarkTest.java:61
Gradle suite > Gradle test > gobblin.source.extractor.watermark.TimestampWatermarkTest.testGetWatermarkConditionSqlServer STARTED
Gradle suite > Gradle test > gobblin.source.extractor.watermark.TimestampWatermarkTest.testGetWatermarkConditionSqlServer FAILED
    java.lang.NullPointerException at TimestampWatermarkTest.java:68

@htran1 I understand what you are saying, but I believe that the current.jst is the cause for many problems. It was discussed a year ago and recommended to be removed. One big issue is that depending on the backing FS, the update of the current file contents is "eventual".  This can lead to incorrect state being returned.

Regarding `#1` above, do you have any numbers that show what the performance is for listing the state files?  Also, what state store implementation are you using.  If it is the FS version, what backing FS is it?

For `#2` I would recommend that we have a different mechanism for moving to a prior state.  This is a good feature, but rewriting the current file seems to be the wrong was to go about this.

As for `#3`, it seems that the need to write a current pointer or not is totally dependent on the filesystem which is used to store the state.  Why not get rid of the concept of current outside of the state store and allow implementations to use it or not.  At least that way, I can make an implementation of FsStateStore that doesn't use current and the builtin version can.

For 1, we are using FS state store on HDFS. I'm less concerned about this case than case 3 on NFS. As long as we retain only a small number of jst files per dataset it will probably be okay since it will probably add at most a few seconds to the startup of a job.

For 2, I'll have to check with the team since this is the current method of temporarily moving state back.

3 is a concern for us since the NFS system we are on is less scalable than HDFS. I'm seeing delete of small files giving only 50 ops/s. Listing should be faster, but with many concurrent jobs starting it may saturate our NFS filer. We only have a single master node in this mode that does job planning, so saving CPU cycles is more essential.

The base state store interface doesn't know about current.jst (at least before your changes). We have other uses of StateStore that stores non .jst files.  The current.jst is a DatasetStateStore concept. So maybe it makes more sense to add the functionality you need to a new variation of FsDatasetStateStore that doesn't make use of the current file. I think you can even add it as a config option to the current FsDatasetStateStore since it should only be a few blocks that are different. In either case, the mysql and zk dataset state stores won't need to be touched. This allows us to continue using current.jst while users of S3 can use the new approach.
@shirshanka Sorry for the delay, I'll get back to this issue this week.
Hi @chavdar, @jinhyukchang can you please take a look?
self-merging since these are utility functions
Looks like this overlaps with #967 and currently doesn't handle the thread pool in the task runner.
Hi @shirshanka , I've changed the implementation to your suggested logic. Tested both the extractor and writer.
Not using this pull request. Closing it now.
Build + tests pass locally. Travis is slooow, merging this in.
@jinhyukchang, wondering if you feel comfortable reviewing this?

@htran1 The JobId/TaskId stuff is needed.  I pulled in a better version from a different PR.  I changed all the other code to just operate on the string versions, but use the Id.* classes to extract the sequence.  Other than that, I rebuilt the commit in a new branch on master as this one was way too messy and had an excessive number of files in it.

This is my initial pull request for better json support for Gobblin. I created the pull request as a conversation starter if this make sense for you in the current form and how to change to fit into your codebase if it make sense for you.
We started to use this module in our environment where logs are in json format.

@htran1 Still trying to figure out the test issue.  I can't get all the tests to run locally because of hive test failures related to metastore_db, so I don't see the failures that are being reported in Travis.

Wooohoooo

--
Joel Baranick
jbaranick@gmail.com

The travis hang does not look related to the code changes and is happening in other PRs.

"Update FsStateStore and ParallelRunner to add this to Hadoop serialization config." 
   What is the implication of not adding it to the serialization config... (if we forgot to fix up all the places)..
The SequenceFile.Reader|Writer will throw an exception saying "I don't know how to write this State class to a SequenceFile". Not great, but it is catchable at unit test time.
@ibuenros Could you take a look when you have a chance?
One other comment, for the clusterIdentifier to be populated correctly, there needs to be a ClustersNames.properties file included.
@ibuenros Thanks for the review and I've addressed PR comments.
@shirshanka addressed the comments around using object attributes instead of instance checks. Also, do you have a suggestion on a better name for `StreamedSource`?
This PR includes the `topic.name` commits as well. Can you please split them?
@htran1 @ibuenros Please review. I will patch another commit on fixing tests.
@htran1 Comments addressed. Also did a rebase.

Hi Piotr - 

Thanks for this contribution!

I haven't looked at the code so this may not be strictly needed, but if we want to keep backwards compatibility I think the right behavior is actually to set:

```sql
start_time TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
end_time TIMESTAMP DEFAULT 0
```

Is it possible for you to verify this on MySQL 5.7 and make sure everything is still working as expected? thanks.

Yes, I'll check it :)

But one question - is `ON UPDATE CURRENT TIMESTAMP` needed in `start_time` field? If record is created after start then updating its `state` column from `RUNNING` to `SUCCEEDED` will change the `start_time` - which is, I think, not a desired behaviour ;) But I'll read the code and check every possible scenario.

Thanks for your comment, Eric :)

So I've checked mysql behaviour with create statements from modified files and made some changes.

Default `sql_mode` variable in MySQL 5.7 contains `NO_ZERO_DATE` and `STRICT_TRANS_TABLES` modifiers: 

```
ONLY_FULL_GROUP_BY,STRICT_TRANS_TABLES,NO_ZERO_IN_DATE,NO_ZERO_DATE,ERROR_FOR_DIVISION_BY_ZERO,NO_AUTO_CREATE_USER,NO_ENGINE_SUBSTITUTION
```

Because of that, MySQL produces an error during creating tables.

`DatabaseJobHistoryV100` class is responsible for inserting values to `gobblin_{job,task}_executions` tables. It checks for `start_time` and `end_time` passed by "user" and converts `null` to `new Timestamp(1)` with UTC `Calendar`. 
I made a change that ensures UTC timezone in the whole db init script and sets appropriate defaults explicitly. Please note that I cannot set `0` as the default value because of `NO_ZERO_DATE` being on by default in MySQL 5.7.

Hope it will be OK :)
Ah, interesting! Thanks for following up, lgtm.
Closing this because there is much more to do to allow clustered Quartz setup, for example: some DAG of dependencies between services starting up in `ServiceBasedAppLauncher`.
Please check both default run group tests are failing: https://travis-ci.org/linkedin/gobblin/builds/219388176

I don't know if you were looking at the same thing, but I noticed EmbeddedDistCp was hanging for me (I was running via the CLI). 

The one-line fix I had was to put a `super.close()` call inside `FileAwareInputStreamDataWriter.close()` -- `InstrumentedDataWriterBase` starts a metrics thread which never gets closed. I don't know why this doesn't break on MR, YARN though. Also not sure if that metrics thread should just be started as a daemon thread so it can't hang the process if not cleaned up properly.
@eogren No, this is a different case of hanging. Is the one you mentioned fix as well?
I think it is a good idea to make the thread daemon as well.
@enjoyear We have to revert this PR because Gobblin does not work with Guava 20. Let's talk about how to maintain compatibility.
@ibuenros Could you take a look when you have a chance? Thanks!
@jinhyukchang I don't quite understand what this PR is achieving. Can you give me a short explanation?

@ibuenros I think the PR subject is misleading and actually the PR is to support credential encryption for ADL as a source using HadoopUtil by passing config prefix that is encrypted. (It's same approach as what's done when it writes to ADL)

https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/blob/master/gobblin-utility/src/main/java/gobblin/util/HadoopUtils.java#L685
@ibuenros Please let me know if you have any doubt. Thanks!
